title: Former Thai PM arrives at court for verdict
description:
(2 Aug 2017) Two former Thai Prime Ministers arrived in court in Bangkok on Wednesday ahead of a verdict in a case filed against them over a decision to move against protesters outside parliament in October 2008, 
Two people were killed and hundreds wounded in the violence.
Somchai Wongsawat was prime minister and Chavalit Yongchaiyudh his deputy at the time.
The clashes turned violent after police fired tear gas to disperse protesters who were trying to block Somchai from delivering his first policy statement to lawmakers.
Somchai was finally able to enter the parliament building but was then trapped inside when the protesters regrouped and blocked the exits.
He had been prime minister for two weeks when the incident happened. 
The protesters wanted him out because they said he was a proxy for Thaksin Shinawatra, who had been deposed in a military coup two years before. 
Somchai is Thaksin's brother-in-law.
Critics of the current military government see the prosecution against Somchai as a further attempt to remove the Shinawatra family from Thai political life.
